RautSoft.math.EQsolve
Class ZeroFinder

java.lang.Object
  RautSoft.math.EQsolve.ZeroFinder

public class ZeroFinder
extends java.lang.Object

The package contains various classes to find zeros of a non-linear function of one variable or a system of non-linear equations of many variables. Currently it has the class ZeroFinder constructed from numerical methods. Unfortunately, the getOptimalSolution(), exitCode etc are not working. They need to be fixed.

Usage Example 

 import static RautSoft.util.nrutil.*;
 import RautSoft.Interfaces.*;
 import RautSoft.math.fsolve.*;

 public class ZeroFinderEX {

 public static void main(String[] args) {

    {Ex1 //Equation of one unknown
 FunctionOfOneVariable f = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
 public double value(double x) {
 return (x-2)*(x-2);
 }
 };

 FunctionOfOneVariable df = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
 public double value(double x) {
 return 2*x -4;
 }
 };
 ZeroFinder zf=new ZeroFinder();
 double xopt = zf.rtnewt(f,df, -10,10,0.0001);
 System.out.println(zf.getLogs() );
 if (zf.getExitCode()==0){
 System.out.println("The optimal solution using rtnewt, xopt = " + xopt);
 }else {System.out.println("Optimal solution could not be obtained, see the errorLog");}
    } //end of Ex1
  { //Ex2 System of equations
 int n=2;
 pBoolean check = new pBoolean(false);
 double []  x = new double [n];
 x[0]=2.0;
 x[1]=0.5;

 VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables  func = new VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables(){
 public double [] value( double[] x){
 double [] f = new double [2];
 f[0]=(x[0]*x[0])+(x[1]*x[1])-2.0;
 f[1]=Math.exp(x[0]-1.0)+x[1]*(x[1]*x[1])-2.0;
 return f;
 }

 };
 newt(x,check,func);
 if (check.value) System.out.println("Convergence problems.");
 for (int i=0;i< n;i++) System.out.printf("x[%d] = %10f and f[%d](x)= %10f\n", i, x[i], i, func.value(x)[i]);
 }
 System.out.println("\nNow try another problem");
  }//End of Ex2

Related Documentations

  • Single Equation of one unknown Example
  • Many equations with with many unknowns using mnewt and mnewtWithoutJacobian(with or without anlytical Jacobian) Example
  • Many equations with with many unknowns using newt (no analytical Jacobian needed ) Example

Constructor Detail

ZeroFinder

Method Detail

rtnewt

public double rtnewt(FunctionOfOneVariable func,
                     FunctionOfOneVariable diff,
                     double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
Returns the solution of a non-linear equation Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of a function known to lie in the interval [x1, x2]. The root rtnewt will be refined until its accuracy is known within ±xacc. funcd is a user-supplied routine that returns both the function value and the first derivative of the function at the point x. The first component of funcd gives the value of the function and the second component gives derivative of the function at a given x

Parameters:
func - equation to be solved, a FunctionOfOneVariable
diff - the first derivative of the function to be solved, a FunctionOfOneVariable
x1 - lower bound of the solution, a double
x2 - upper bound of the solution, a double
xacc - the accuracy sought ±xacc. a double such as 1.0e-10
Returns:
solution of the non-linear equation func = 0, a double

rtsafe

public double rtsafe(FunctionOfOneVariable func,
                     FunctionOfOneVariable diff,
                     double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
Using a combination of Newton-Raphson and bisection, find the root of a function bracketed between x1 and x2. The root, returned as the function value rtsafe, will be refined until its accuracy is known within ±xacc. funcd is a user-supplied routine that returns both the function value and the first derivative of the function.

Parameters:
func - equation to be solved, a FunctionOfOneVariable
diff - the first derivative of the function to be solved, a FunctionOfOneVariable
x1 - lower bound of the solution, a double
x2 - upper bound of the solution, a double
xacc - the accuracy sought ±xacc. a double such as 1.0e-10
Returns:
solution of the non-linear equation func = 0, a double

newt

public void newt(VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables fvec,
                 double[] x,
                 nrutil.pBoolean check)
Given an initial guess x[0..n-1] for a root in n dimensions, find the root by a globally convergent Newton’s method. The vector of functions to be zeroed, called fvec[0..n-1], is of type VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables. The output quantity check is false (0) on a normal return and true (1) if the routine has converged to a local minimum of the function fmin defined below. In this case try restarting from a different initial guess.

Parameters:
fvec - the system of equaitons, a VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables object
check - a pBoolean object, check.value = false means convergence problem is false
x - initial values, a 1-D array, on return also contain the optimal solution.

mnewt

public void mnewt(VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables fn,
                  MatrixOfFunctionsOfManyVariables jack,
                  double[] x,
                  double tolx,
                  double tolf,
                  int ntrial)
On return, x contains improved root starting from a given initial guess x[0..n-1] for a root in n dimensions, take ntrial Newton-Raphson steps to improve the root. Stop if the root converges in either summed absolute variable increments tolx or summed absolute function values tolf.

Parameters:
jack - Jackobian of the function of many variables, a MatrixOfFunctionsOfManyVariables object
ntrial - number of trials
x - a 1-D double array of initial values, on return x contains the optimal solution
tolx - the tolerance of x values, a double
tolf - the tolerance limit of the function values, a double
fn - system of non-linear functions of several variables whose 0 to be found, a VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables object

mnewtWithoutJackbobian

public void mnewtWithoutJackbobian(VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables fn,
                                   double[] x)
On return, x contains improved root starting from a given initial guess x[0..n-1] for a root in n dimensions, take default NTRIALS=10, TOLX=1.0e-15, TOLF=1.0e-15 to carry out Newton-Raphson steps to improve the root. Stop if the root converges in either summed absolute variable increments TOLX or summed absolute function values TOLF. The default values could be reset by creating an object of ZeroFinderNR type and then setting the values for these static fields as follows. 
 ZeroFinder zro=new ZeroFinder();
 nr.NTRIALS=5;
 nr.TOLX=1.0e-15;
 nr.TOLF=1.0e-15 ;
Now on the default values for these static fields in ZeroFinderNR class will be reset to these. See also RautSoft.math.fsolve.ZeroFinderNR#mnewt(VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables fn, MatrixOfFunctionsOfManyVariables jack, double [] x, double tolx, double tolf,int ntrial) .

Parameters:
x - a 1-D double array of initial values, on return x contains the optimal solution
fn - system of non-linear functions of several variables whose 0 to be found, a VectorOfFunctionsOfManyVariables object

getOptimalSolution

public double[] getOptimalSolution()
Returns the optimal solution as a 1-D double array only for equaitons with more than one unknowns. Check if getas the double solution only for problems with more than one variables. Caution: getExitCode should return 0 to make sure that the numerical algorithm indeed produced an optimal solution.

Returns:
optimal solution, a 1-D double array.

getExitCode

public int getExitCode()
Returns the exitCode, an int, = 0 solution obtained, =-1, the algorithm did not converge.

Returns:
exitCode, an int

getOutput

public java.lang.String getOutput()
get accessor method for output

Returns:
output, a String object

getLogs

public java.lang.String getLogs()
get accessor method for errorlogs.

Returns:
logs and errors, a String object
